issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
My notes during my Console Guide review ( I have also attached an easier to read formatted version):

An overall note, for accessing local files, the docs say to click the "Browse" button, however, in Chrome, the button is labeled "Choose File"
1. 
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_config_ssl_certs.html

"Uncomment and modify the the SSL certificate paths in /eucaconsole/conf/nginx.conf. For example:"

 The path/file noted here does not exist.
I found this file here: /usr/share/doc/eucaconsole-4.0.0/nginx.conf


2.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_dashboard.html

Under Network and Security, step 3.
"Create elastic IP address ", I actually see "Allocate elastic IPs"

3.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_manage_security_groups.html
Viewing Details of a Security Group

You can expand a security group in the list to see details about the security group, including tags and rules associated with the security group.

Click the name of the security group in the list of security groups.
The area beneath the security group name will expand to a tabbed interface.
Click the General tab to see a panel of detailed information about the security group, include the list of incoming traffic rules.
Click the Tags tab to see a list of tags associated with the security group.
This section should be changed.  On option 1, if you click the name of the security group, it does not expand underneath the name, it goes to a separate page.  For options 2 & 3, there are no tabs, just a view of detailed information about the security groups.

4.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_usage_volumes_intro.html

     Volume Detail - Snapshots
     This page shows you the details for a volume.
Should this say "This page shows you the snapshots related to the volume."?

5.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_manage_volumes.html
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_manage_instances.html

Searching and Filtering the Volumes List
To perform a simple search/filter, type some search text into the search text box at the top right of the page.
For more precise filtering and searching, you can add one or more filters by clicking one of the availabile filters in the Filter by section on the right side of the page.
The text "right side" on step 2 should be changed to "left side".  Also "availabile" should be "available".
This repeats in other sections of the documentation.  If I catch them, I will post the links related here.

6.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_volume_detail_snapshots.html

Snapshots

This section allows you to view and manage snapshots associated with the volume.

Create a new snapshot

Click the Create a snapshot icon to display the Create snapshot from volume dialog.
In the following section, "Create a snapshot icon", 'icon' should actually be 'tab'.

7.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_delete_volumes.html
Verify Volume Deletion 

To verify that you wish to delete the selected volume(s), click the Yes, Delete button.
To cancel the delete operation, click the Cancel button.
In Step 2, the Cancel button is actually the X in the upper right corner.
8.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_manage_instances.html
Stop

Select this item to stop the selected instance.
I believe you can only stop an EBS backed instance.  

9.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_instance_detail.html
On this page, the Add Tags section is listed twice.

10.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_instance_detail_volumes.html
Context menu actions

Each tile in the volume list has a context menu. Clicking the action icon in the upper right corner of a volume tile brings up a menu of actions that you can perform on the selected snapshot.

'snapshot' should be 'volume'.

11.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_create_instances.html
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_create_scaling_group.html

4. To help you manage your cloud's instances, images, and other Eucalyptus resources, you can optionally assign your own metadata to each resource in the form of tags. You can use tags to create user-friendly names, make resource searching easier, and improve coordination between multiple users. To add tags to this resource:
    a. Type the key name for your tag into the Key text box.
    b. Type the value for your tag into the Value text box.
    c. To add this tag, click the Add Tag button to the right of the Value text box.
    d. If you wish to delete a tag that you've already entered, click the x button to the right of the tag.

Item 'a' shows 'Key text box' but the Console shows 'name...' text box
Item 'c': the 'Add Tag' button is underneath the text fields not on the right.

12.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_create_instances.html
Specify Advanced Options

This panel allows you to specify advanced options for your new instance(s). You can add user data, override the kernel and RAM disk IDs, specify private networking, and add additional storage.

Specify custom user data by typing it into the User data text box or by attaching a file by clicking the Browse... button.
You can override the kernel ID in the selected image with the Kernel ID drop-down list box.
You can override the RAM disk ID in the selected image with the RAM disk ID (RAMFS) drop-down list box.
Click the Enable monitoring check box to specify that detailed CloudWatch metric gathering should be enabled for your new instance(s).
Click the Use private addressing only check box to specify that your new instance should use private addressing only. Private addresses cannot connect directly to the Internet and must go through a NAT (Network Address Translation) device or an elastic IP address mapped to the instance.
You can configure additional storage for your instance in the Storage section:
Select a volume type using the Volume drop-down list box.
Type the desired mapping for the storage into the Mapping text box (for example: /dev/sdb).
If you want to create the storage from an existing snapshot, specify it in the Create from snapshot drop-down list box.
Type the size of the attached storage in gigabytes into the Size (GB) text box.
Select the Delete on termination check box if you would like the attached storage to be deleted when the instance is terminated.
Click the Add device button to add this storage.
You can delete storage you've already added by clicking the minus button on the right side of the storage list item.
Click the Launch instance(s) button to launch your new instance(s).
Item 6: I did not see any additional Storage option in the Advanced section


13.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_launch_more_instances.html
Add Tags

To help you manage your cloud's instances, images, and other Eucalyptus resources, you can optionally assign your own metadata to each resource in the form of tags. You can use tags to create user-friendly names, make resource searching easier, and improve coordination between multiple users. This panel allows you to specify tags for your new instance(s).

To help you manage your cloud's instances, images, and other Eucalyptus resources, you can optionally assign your own metadata to each resource in the form of tags. You can use tags to create user-friendly names, make resource searching easier, and improve coordination between multiple users. To add tags to your new instance(s):
Type the key name for your tag into the Key text box.
Type the value for your tag into the Value text box.
To add this tag, click the Add Tag button to the right of the Value text box.
If you wish to delete a tag that you've already entered, click the x button to the right of the tag.
I did not see the 'Add Tags' section on the 'Launch more instances like' page.
Under the 'Specify Advanced Option', item 6 talks about additional storage, however I did not see this option in the GUI.

14.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_terminate_instances.html
Verify Instance Termination

Verify that you wish to terminate the selected instance(s). You may click the x button on the instance ID to remove the instance from the list of instances to be deleted.
To terminate the instance(s), click the Yes, Terminate button.
To cancel the terminate operation, click the x button in the upper right corner of the dialog box.
Option 1, there was not way to select multiple instances to terminate.

15.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_manage_scaling_groups.html
Deleting scaling group

This item allows you to delete a scaling group.
Note: This menu item will not appear if the volume is attached to an instance.
The 'Note:' item, may be incorrect.  I don't see a way to attach volumes, only instances, and the delete option is there even when an instance is attached.

16.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_create_scaling_group.html

General
This section is where you specify the basic configuration of your new auto scaling group.

Type the name of your new auto scaling group in the Name textbox.
Select a launch configuration from the Launch Configuration drop-down list box. A launch configuration defines the properties of the instances that are launched as part of your auto scaling group.
Select the maximum number of instances you want running in your autoscaling group using the Maximum control.
Specify the minimum number of instances you want running using the Minimum control.
Specify the desired number of instance you want running using the Desired control.
Options 3-5 are not in the top section of the General tab, they are covered in the Capacity section.

17.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_delete_scaling_group.html
Verify Scaling Group Deletion

To verify that you wish to delete the selected scaling group, click the Yes, delete button.
To cancel the delete operation, click the Cancel button.
The Cancel button is actually an X in the upper right corner.

18.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_manage_launch_configs.html
Each entry in the launh configurations list has a context menu, accessible in the Actions column. Clicking the action icon brings up a menu of actions that you can perform on the selected snapshot.
launh should be 'launch'

19.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_create_launch_config.html

Specify Advanced Options
This panel allows you to specify advanced options for the new instance in your auto scaling group. You can add user data, override the kernel and RAM disk IDs, specify private networking, and add additional storage.

Specify custom user data by typing it into the User data text box or by attaching a file by clicking the Choose file button.
You can override the kernel ID in the selected image with the Kernel ID drop-down list box.
You can override the RAM disk ID in the selected image with the RAM disk ID drop-down list box.
You can configure additional storage for your instance in the Storage section:
Select a volume type using the Volume drop-down list box.
Type the desired mapping for the storage into the Mapping text box (for example: /dev/sdb).
If you want to create the storage from an existing snapshot, specify it in the Create from snapshot drop-down list box.
Type the size of the attached storage in gigabytes into the Size (GB) text box.
Select the Delete on termination check box if you would like the attached storage to be deleted when the instance is terminated.
Click the Add device button to add this storage.
You can delete storage you've already added by clicking the minus button on the right side of the storage list item.
Click the Create launch configuration button.
Option 4: I didn't see this section from the GUI Console

20.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_create_launch_config_from_instance.html
Name Your Launch Configuration

This panel allows you to enter a name for your new launch configuration. It also displays the platform, type, and keypair/security group for your launch instance; these values are derived from the instance you had selected in the Manage instances landing page and cannot be changed.

Type the name of your new launch configuration into the Launch configuration name text box.
Click the Advanced tab to proceed to the specify advanced options, or click the Create launch configuration button to create your new launch configuration.
On step 2: You can't click the Advanced tab from this point.  You have to click the next button to go to the Security tab first.  You also cannot click the Create launch configuration button from this point.
There is no information about the security tab on this page.

21.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_create_snapshot.html

Snapshot
Add the details of your snapshot:

Enter a name for the volume in the Name text box.
'volume' should be 'snapshot'

22.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_release_eip.html
To verify that you wish to release the selected IP address(es), click the Yes, release button.
To cancel the delete operation, click the Cancel button.
Item 2 should be an X not Cancel.

23.
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/console_manage_iam_users.html

Context menu actions
Each entry in the image list has a context menu, accessible in the Actions column. Clicking the action icon brings up a menu of actions that you can perform on the selected user.

The following context menu actions are availabe:
View details

This item will bring up the user detail page.
Disable

This item deletes a user's password and creates an IAM access "deny all actions" policy that prevents them from executing any actions against the cloud. The user's other information, including active access keys, is maintained until you either make the user active again or delete them.
Disable 

This action enables a previously disable user and removes the IAM "deny all actions" policy. You will need to create a new password to allow the user to login.
Delete

This item allows you to delete a user.
Note: This menu item deletes a user and all keys, passwords and permissions associated with that user.

'Disable' is mentioned twice.  The 2nd Disable should be Enable.
